title: ADA Holders Functioning as Banks
description: 多くの人は、単独で投資できるほどの資金を持っていないし、時には小口の融資を受ける資格すらない。

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal doesn't make it clear how they are actually using metadata to make this work. They state it could be possible to use metadata to calculate a borrowers score. 
This is key to the proposal. Without an ability to estimate whether a borrower will repay, how can you decide whether to lend, and what is a reasonable rate.  
Why would a borrower even repay at all? What is the mechanism? Allowing ADA holders act as a bank could be a good business, but lending can only happen with a requirement to repay, and  information on likelihood of repayment.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer does not provide any experience in relation to banking, which is the core of this proposal. No plan has been provided on how to evaluate credit quality, set lending rates, manage delinquencies etc. A detailed plan on who this ADA bank will be run and why lenders would use it should be proivded.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer should provide deliverables and a timeline for producing them. He should also show why both sides would use this (lenders and borrowers). How are they going to be attracted. Is there a marketing plan? What is success? Total value lent, number of lenders/borrowers, default and lending rates relative to commercial banks?

f6_assessments.q0: I like the idea of having a peer-to-peer loaning system. What is unclear for me is the problem itself. It is vaguely described as in for what loans do you mean? If you're talking about loans in the world I don't see this working out since it is not without huge risks. Banks won't see crypto as valuable liquidity for loans, and if you give out a loan on the dApp and the loaner needs to cash it first then how will the dApp seize the assets back?   And why did you propose this under metadata challenge if your goal is to create a dApp?
f6_assessments.q1: The Github link provided by the proposer indicates that he has the necessary skills for this branch. But as far as I can see you still need other people on the team to completely develop this proposal, which is not mentioned in the proposal. The proposal is also missing a clear budget breakdown which makes it unclear what you truly need the funding for. You also don't have a timetable worked out where we can track the process being made. Since there is not much to go with to assess the feasibility of this proposal I disagree that the proposal can successfully be implemented.
f6_assessments.q2: Since the proposal is missing a roadmap/milestones it is challenging to assess the auditability of this proposal. Since only a Github link is posted we also don't have that much background on the proposer. Provide more information on how you plan to make this proposal work and what milestone you wish to achieve while working on this.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal could be in an incorrect community challenge. It does not directly explain how the challenge will solve real-world problems and it does not show the value that the proposers are offering
f6_assessments.q1: There is no clarity on what the proposer will contribute to the success of a proposal. The proposal does not provide any details on the plan and how it will be implemented. There needs to be more detailed information on the proposer plan to inspire more confidence among Catalyst voters
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal is vague. I would expect an appropriate level of depth when addressing how the budget is going to be spent. I tried to open every attachment and read through all segments - but found no further clarification on this project. I am alsounable to establish experience. The proposal itself reads very poorly. It reads like a concept more than an executable proposal. It needs more editing so that it can be assessed properly given its direction. Perhaps reworking it and submitting it at the later stages will work

f6_assessments.q0: It is not clear how this proposal utilizes metadata to enable banking-lending functions as it does not involve anti-tampering, event confirmation, document existence confirmation, or personally identifying data obfuscation. This proposal may have been submitted to this challenge by mistake.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposer offers insufficient evidence of his skills needed to implement the proposal. The budget is general and is not broken down via a budget narrative or line-item list. The proposal offers no timetable for project work and does not describe the resources necessary to implement the proposal. The proposal does not unpack the technical aspects of the project.
f6_assessments.q2: No milestones are provided, no metrics are offered. Furthermore while there is a general description it would benefit from additional depth.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal statement and solution do not refer to a transaction metadata problem as described in this challenge. Moreover, the details section of the proposal describes the solution to the loan problem and only includes a reference to metadata at the end. Reading in detail the solution proposed it is not possible to understand how this proposal is aligned to the challenge. Note that this challenge is for projects or POCs where metadata solve the problem of traceability, authentication, and/or auditability for example. I recommend developing the idea behind metadata or check if other Challenges are better fits for your proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal elaborates the functional process of the idea. However, it does not provide an actionable plan with steps and deliverables. Based on the lack of that fundamental information it is not possible to assume that the project is feasible or has a possibility of success. I recommend developing the idea with a detail plan.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal does not provide deliverables, timelines, or metrics that can be audited by the community. Note that it is important for Project Catalyst to be able to track progress of project where funds are allocated. The proposal states an overall budget but do not specify for what activities is needed. For those reasons I do not consider that there's enough information to audit the progress.
